course.subject: EMIA
course.name: Cross-disciplinary Seminar: Artificial Intelligence
course.description: A compulsory course for students enrolling in the extended major programs throughout their course of study. It is a seminar series presented by faculty members and guest speakers on interdisciplinary topics in extended major area and its applications related to the major. For students with extended major in their second year of study only. Graded P or F.

reviews.author: ちきばん
reviews.title: Everyone can learn something from it :)
reviews.comment_content:
From what on earth is AI/ML to actual AI applications, from the maths behind GAN (talking about f-divergence after just 10 slides) to a downright Huawei commercial, you'll find yourself on a rollercoaster across seminars of drastically varying difficulties, from thinking "I can catch up" to realising that the first seminar gives you false comfort of what'd be on the menu next week. You can definitely learn something from it, irrespective of your background in AI :D

I'd give an A if there's some indication of the depth of each seminar. Some are targeted at laymen whereas some go very deep - very enriching but students with less background knowledge will find it very hard to follow.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Seminar 1: Gentle Intro to ML (by Prof. DY Yeung) - AI in layman's terms, not bad
Seminar 2: Intro to Modern Conversational AI (by Prof. Pascale Fung) - now it starts to get exciting
Seminar 3: Huawei commercial (by Dr Jia Zeng at Huawei Noah's Ark Lab) - give me a Skip Ad button pls
Seminar 4: Deep Generative Model Learning and its Application (by Prof. Can Yang) - the slides are intimidating! luckily I passed the course already so I don't really care
Seminar 5: (You'll be told the arrangements if you didn't attend 3 out of the above 4 seminars)
reviews.comment_workload:
Attend 3 seminars F2F and take the quiz right at the end of each seminar - and voila! That's much lighter than ENGG2010!

Jot some keywords during the seminar and the quizzes are no-brainers! You can also have your attentive friend do it for you.

If you're in T2 (the video recording section), you can also choose to watch the recordings online - in RVC (meh) quality - just remember to submit a 500-word essay for each seminar for your attendance to count.
